sub.title: Adult Dosing
sub.mono:
• mifamurtide has centralized marketing authorization by the European Medicines Agency (EMA) for use in the European Union (EU)
  • use in adults older than 30 years not recommended
  • Osteosarcoma of bone, High-grade, resectable, non-metastatic; adjuvant therapy after macroscopically complete surgical resection: (younger than 30 years) 2 mg/m(2) infused IV over 1 hour twice weekly, separated by 3 days, for 12 weeks, then once weekly for additional 24 weeks; total 48 infusions in 36 weeks (European Medicines Agency-approved dosing)

sub.title: Pediatric Dosing
sub.mono:
• safety and efficacy not established in pediatric patients younger than 2 years
  • Osteosarcoma of bone, High-grade, resectable, non-metastatic; adjuvant therapy after macroscopically complete surgical resection: (2 years or older) 2 mg/m(2) infused IV over 1 hour twice weekly, separated by 3 days, for 12 weeks, then once weekly for additional 24 weeks; total 48 infusions in 36 weeks (European Medicines Agency-approved dosing)

sub.title: Dose Adjustments
sub.mono:
• concomitant use with renally toxic chemotherapy agents: no dose adjustment necessary
  • concomitant use with hepatotoxic chemotherapy agents: no dose adjustment necessary

sub.title: Indications
sub.mono:
Non-FDA Labeled Indications
Osteosarcoma of bone, High-grade, resectable, non-metastatic; adjuvant therapy after macroscopically complete surgical resection

sub.title: Contraindications
sub.mono:
• hypersensitivity to mifamurtide or any product excipients
  • concomitant use with cyclosporine or other calcineurin inhibitors
  • concomitant use with high-dose NSAIDs or cyclooxygenase inhibitors

sub.title: Precautions
sub.mono:
• allergic reactions, serious (ie, shortness of breath, grade 4 hypertension), have occurred; may be difficult to differentiate from exaggerated inflammatory response; monitoring recommended
  • autoimmune, inflammatory, or other collagen diseases, history; increased risk of pronounced inflammatory response; monitoring recommended
  • concomitant use with chronic or routine corticosteroid therapy should be avoided
  • hepatic impairment; monitoring recommended
  • neutropenia, generally in combination with chemotherapy, has occurred; monitoring recommended if fever present; assess for sepsis with persistent (greater than 8 hours) fever or chills after administration
  • renal impairment; monitoring recommended
  • respiratory distress has been reported; increased risk with history of asthma or COPD; consider prophylaxis with bronchodilators; discontinue use if suspected
  • venous thrombosis, vasculitis, or unstable cardiovascular disorders, history; symptoms may persist and worsen during therapy; delay or discontinuation of therapy may be required; monitoring recommended

5.title: Adverse Effects
5.mono:
Common
  • Cardiovascular:Chest pain (11%), Tachycardia (More than 50%)
  • Dermatologic:Hyperhidrosis (11%)
  • Endocrine metabolic:Hypothermia (23%)
  • Gastrointestinal:Constipation (17%), Diarrhea (13%), Loss of appetite (21%), Nausea (57%), Vomiting (44%)
  • Hematologic:Anemia (10% or greater), Neutropenic disorder
  • Musculoskeletal:Arthralgia (10%), Backache (15%), Myalgia (31%), Pain in limb (12%)
  • Neurologic:Asthenia (13%), Dizziness (17%), Headache (50%)
  • Respiratory:Cough (18%), Dyspnea (21%), Tachypnea (13%)
  • Other:Fatigue (53%), Fever (85%), Malaise (13%), Pain (15%), Shivering (89%)
Serious
  • Dermatologic:Cellulitis (1% to less than 10%)
  • Hematologic:Febrile neutropenia (1% to less than 10%), Myelodysplastic syndrome (2.1%)
  • Immunologic:Hypersensitivity reaction, Inflammatory disorder
  • Otic:Hearing loss (1% to 12%)
  • Other:Cyanosis (1% to less than 10%), Sepsis (1% to less than 10%)

9.title: Administration
9.mono:
• General Information
    do not administer as a bolus injection
  • Intravenous
    • allow vial to reach room temperature before reconstitution (approximately 30 minutes)
    • withdraw 50 mL NS from 100-mL NS infusion bag and reconstitute using filter provided to bring vial concentration to 0.08 mg/mL
    • filter and syringe must not be removed from vial until reconstitution process completed
    • after reconstitution, let vial stand for 1 minute, then shake vigorously for 1 minute for liposome formation
    • withdraw desired dose, inject back into original infusion bag, and infuse IV over 1 hour
    • administer prepared solution immediately if possible; reconstituted vial contents stable for 6 hours at room temperature (between approximately 25 to 25 degrees C)
    • separate administration times of mifamurtide and doxorubicin or other lipophilic agents
